articles.headline: Suicide Bombing in Israel Kills 9; Hamas Approves
articles.snippet: The president of the Palestinian Authority condemned the attack, reflecting a split in the Palestinian leadership.
articles.abstract: The president of the Palestinian Authority condemned the attack, reflecting a split in the Palestinian leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV, April 17 — A Palestinian suicide bomber carried out the deadliest attack on Israel in almost two years on Monday when he detonated his explosives at a falafel restaurant in Tel Aviv — an act that Hamas, which leads the new Palestinian government, called legitimate.
articles.byline: By GREG MYRE and DINA KRAFT

articles.headline: Babylon Awaits an Iraq Without Fighting
articles.snippet: Iraqi leaders and U.N. officials are working assiduously to restore the war-ravaged ancient city.
articles.abstract: Iraqi leaders and U.N. officials are working assiduously to restore the war-ravaged ancient city.
articles.lead_paragraph: BABYLON, Iraq — In this ancient city, it is hard to tell what are ruins and what's just ruined.

articles.headline: Evacuee Study Finds Declining Health
articles.snippet: Families displaced by Hurricane Katrina are much more likely to have chronic conditions and a lack of insurance.
articles.abstract: Families displaced by Hurricane Katrina are much more likely to have chronic conditions and a lack of insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Families displaced by Hurricane Katrina are suffering from mental disorders and chronic conditions like asthma and from a lack of prescription medication and health insurance at rates that are much higher than average, a new study has found.

articles.headline: Benchmark Unsought: Oil Over $70
articles.snippet: Oil futures prices surged to a record yesterday, settling above $70 a barrel amid concern over Iran's nuclear program and continuing shortages in production in Nigeria.     Crude oil for May delivery rose $1.08, to $70.40 a barrel, the highest lev...
articles.abstract: Oil futures prices surged to a record yesterday, settling above $70 a barrel amid concern over Iran's nuclear program and continuing shortages in production in Nigeria.     Crude oil for May delivery rose $1.08, to $70.40 a barrel, the highest level at the end of a trading session since the contract was introduced on the exchange in March 1983. The price was short of an intraday high of $70.85 a barrel touched on Aug. 30, after Hurricane Katrina shut down production in the Gulf of Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oil futures prices surged to a record yesterday, settling above $70 a barrel amid concern over Iran's nuclear program and continuing shortages in production in Nigeria.

articles.headline: Chemical Companies Look to Coal as an Oil Substitute
articles.snippet: Coal for fuel? Pretty common. But coal as the main ingredient in wall paints, fertilizers, even grocery bags?     With oil and natural gas prices showing no signs of plummeting, and with incentives to use coal built into the Energy Policy Act of 2...
articles.abstract: Coal for fuel? Pretty common. But coal as the main ingredient in wall paints, fertilizers, even grocery bags?     With oil and natural gas prices showing no signs of plummeting, and with incentives to use coal built into the Energy Policy Act of 2005, it just might happen. And chemical companies, which use oil and gas as feedstocks -- industry jargon for raw materials -- are hoping it will happen soon.

articles.headline: Evacuee Study Finds Declining Health
articles.snippet: Families displaced by Hurricane Katrina are suffering from mental disorders and chronic conditions like asthma and from a lack of prescription medication and health insurance at rates that are much higher than average, a new study has found.      ...
articles.abstract: Families displaced by Hurricane Katrina are suffering from mental disorders and chronic conditions like asthma and from a lack of prescription medication and health insurance at rates that are much higher than average, a new study has found.      The study, conducted by the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University and the Children's Health Fund, is the first to examine the health issues of those living in housing provided by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Based on face-to-face interviews with more than 650 families living in trailers or hotels, it provides a grim portrait of the hurricane's effects on some of the poorest victims, showing gaps in the tattered safety net pieced together from government and private efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Families displaced by Hurricane Katrina are suffering from mental disorders and chronic conditions like asthma and from a lack of prescription medication and health insurance at rates that are much higher than average, a new study has found.

articles.headline: New Chief of Staff Sends Message: The White House Exits Are Open
articles.snippet: The new White House chief of staff put the West Wing and official Washington on notice on Monday about potentially substantial changes in the way the White House is staffed and operates.     Meeting first thing Monday with senior White House aides...
articles.abstract: The new White House chief of staff put the West Wing and official Washington on notice on Monday about potentially substantial changes in the way the White House is staffed and operates.     Meeting first thing Monday with senior White House aides, the new chief, Joshua B. Bolten, said it was time to ''refresh and re-energize'' President Bush's team, the White House press secretary, Scott McClellan, said. Mr. Bolten also said anybody who was considering leaving within the year should step forward now, according to Mr. McClellan's account of the meeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 17 - The new White House chief of staff put the West Wing and official Washington on notice on Monday about potentially substantial changes in the way the White House is staffed and operates.

articles.headline: Babylon Awaits an Iraq Without Fighting
articles.snippet: In this ancient city, it is hard to tell what are ruins and what's just ruined.      Crumbling brick buildings, some 2,500 years old, look like smashed sand castles at the beach.
articles.abstract: In this ancient city, it is hard to tell what are ruins and what's just ruined.      Crumbling brick buildings, some 2,500 years old, look like smashed sand castles at the beach.
articles.lead_paragraph: BABYLON, Iraq - In this ancient city, it is hard to tell what are ruins and what's just ruined.

articles.headline: Academia Dissects the Service Sector, but Is It a Science?
articles.snippet: On his Asian trip last month, President Bush urged Americans not to fear the rise toward prosperity of emerging economies like India. Education, Mr. Bush said, was the best response to globalization, climbing further up the ladder of skills to ''f...
articles.abstract: On his Asian trip last month, President Bush urged Americans not to fear the rise toward prosperity of emerging economies like India. Education, Mr. Bush said, was the best response to globalization, climbing further up the ladder of skills to ''fill the jobs of the 21st century.''     But a ladder to where? That is, where are educated young Americans likely to find good jobs that will not be shipped off to India or China?
articles.lead_paragraph: On his Asian trip last month, President Bush urged Americans not to fear the rise toward prosperity of emerging economies like India. Education, Mr. Bush said, was the best response to globalization, climbing further up the ladder of skills to "fill the jobs of the 21st century."

articles.headline: Suicide Bombing in Israel Kills 9; Hamas Approves
articles.snippet: A Palestinian suicide bomber carried out the deadliest attack on Israel in almost two years on Monday when he detonated his explosives at a falafel restaurant in Tel Aviv -- an act that Hamas, which leads the new Palestinian government, called leg...
articles.abstract: A Palestinian suicide bomber carried out the deadliest attack on Israel in almost two years on Monday when he detonated his explosives at a falafel restaurant in Tel Aviv -- an act that Hamas, which leads the new Palestinian government, called legitimate.      Nine people and the bomber were killed and dozens wounded in the blast, at a small restaurant that was hit by a suicide bomber just three months ago, on Jan. 19. In that attack, 20 Israelis were injured.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV, April 17 - A Palestinian suicide bomber carried out the deadliest attack on Israel in almost two years on Monday when he detonated his explosives at a falafel restaurant in Tel Aviv -- an act that Hamas, which leads the new Palestinian government, called legitimate.
articles.byline: By Greg Myre and Dina Kraft

articles.headline: A Farewell to Citigroup
articles.snippet: Entering his sun-filled office in Citigroup's Manhattan headquarters, Sanford I. Weill punched a few buttons on a computer near a window before looking over his shoulder and smiling broadly. When asked if he had just looked at Citigroup's stock pr...
articles.abstract: Entering his sun-filled office in Citigroup's Manhattan headquarters, Sanford I. Weill punched a few buttons on a computer near a window before looking over his shoulder and smiling broadly. When asked if he had just looked at Citigroup's stock price, he shrugged his shoulders as if to suggest he could not help himself.     ''It's up 35 cents; it's a good day,'' he noted.
articles.lead_paragraph: Entering his sun-filled office in Citigroup's Manhattan headquarters, Sanford I. Weill punched a few buttons on a computer near a window before looking over his shoulder and smiling broadly. When asked if he had just looked at Citigroup's stock price, he shrugged his shoulders as if to suggest he could not help himself.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Eric Dash

articles.headline: U.S. Takes First Shots at Skilling
articles.snippet: A prosecutor in the Enron fraud trial bore in on the credibility of Jeffrey K. Skilling on multiple fronts Monday, suggesting that the former chief executive knew the company was in trouble when he tried to sell shares and that he failed to disclo...
articles.abstract: A prosecutor in the Enron fraud trial bore in on the credibility of Jeffrey K. Skilling on multiple fronts Monday, suggesting that the former chief executive knew the company was in trouble when he tried to sell shares and that he failed to disclose his interest in a small company run by a former girlfriend.     After a week of making strident denials that he conspired to defraud Enron's investors, Mr. Skilling withstood a barrage of questions as the prosecutor, Sean M. Berkowitz, the head of the Justice Department's Enron Task Force, opened his cross-examination. Legal specialists consider Mr. Skilling's cross-examination a crucial phase of the trial, now in its 12th week.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, April 17 - A prosecutor in the Enron fraud trial bore in on the credibility of Jeffrey K. Skilling on multiple fronts Monday, suggesting that the former chief executive knew the company was in trouble when he tried to sell shares and that he failed to disclose his interest in a small company run by a former girlfriend.
articles.byline: By Alexei Barrionuevo and Vikas Bajaj
